segments.text: Hey, a what's up?

segments.speaker: F

segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yeah.

segments.speaker: M

segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It's okay.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: 'Cause, you know, you've got all the times that you guys did spend together, you know and that's something good that you can look back on.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I mean--I don't know.

segments.text: And his whole family was there.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well, that's that's good, you know.  At least, I don't know.  I mean it's- it's better to go- to goout that way than...
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: .than you know, in pain and like this gradual, this horrible process.  I mean--
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: He was so young, you know.  And all the stories he used to tell me about...

segments.text: ...the way he wanted to live and he was gonna go to Africa and he was gonna--
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: But look at the--he--look at the life he did get to lead.  I mean, for his age, he'd done so much and--

segments.speaker: M

segments.text: And you'll always have that and--you should feel, you know, happy for him that he got to do so much before--I mean, and even after he found out last year.  I mean--
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: He did a lot.  But--
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I know.  It doesn't bring him back, but--

segments.text: That will be, It'll be--it'll be better that way. I mean Time will tell.  Time heals, you know, and it's good.  It's okay.  I mean, it wasn't anybody's fault or anything like that so .
